children.subject: There's another post here that says the class won't be expanded I think. Not sure though.

Just because the class is large this semester doesn't mean that it'll be that large next semester. Class sizes are limited by funds for hiring staff members and by having a classroom that can fit the class.

Hm. I thought the initial capacity, in most cases, is supposed to be ~70% of what it will eventually be (that's what the enrollment policy says..) which would imply the capacity will be expanded to about 408/.7 = 583 (unless they can't find enough TAs).

No, 408 is the projected capacity (assuming enough TAs can be hired), and 408 * 0.7 = 285.6 would be the current cap on enrollment according to that policy.

And indeed, 287 is the number that the enrollment is frozen at currently.
Oh, I see... thanks for the clarification.

Where did you hear that there are no plans to expand it? In previous semesters the class has 500-600 people, e.g. this semester (Fall 2016) it has 592 enrolled which is more than the the current enrolled + waitlisted numbers for Spring 2017 (287 + 291 = 578).

history.content:
Assuming all 121 seats free up and 121 students get off the waitlist, there's still 30% of the class size on the waitlist already.

Depending on where you are, the chances may be large or small, but you can compare to the usual 10% rule of thumb as a reference.

The class is much smaller than in past semesters, so I don't think enrollment patterns is a good indicator.

I'm declaring CS this semester, and am currently waitlisted for CS170. How likely is it that I will make it into the class, provided that I declare?

I've heard on one hand that usually people who declare get in because they are taken off the waitlist and placed into the course, and on the other hand that CS170 is already full and there are no plans to expand, so I'll most likely not make it.

Many thanks.
history.subject: Waitlisted for CS170
